organization.$: Department of Mathematics and Computer Science

head.citation-title: Diagnosing the English as a foreign language (EFL) reading problems using two-step cluster analysis
head.abstracts: © 2016 IEEE.The propose of this research was to classify the English as a foreign language (EFL) learners based on their performance on the reading test. Three levels of reading comprehension are customarily defined: (1) Factual level or Reading the lines, (2) Interpretive level or Reading between the lines, and (3) Evaluative level or Reading beyond the lines. Further analyzing and synthesizing factors underlying these comprehension levels, 10 reading skills were extracted: (1) Explicitly stated meanings, (2) Vocabulary in context, (3) Facts and opinions (4) Pronoun reference,(5) Linking words and grammatical structures, (6) Main ideas and supporting details,(7) Text structure, (8) Inferred meanings,(9) Author's purpose, and (10) Author's viewpoint. The Two-Step Cluster Analysis was performed on reading test scores of 297 first-year college students. The precluster step performed on the test scores of 10 reading skills of the 297 students generated three subclusters: Subcluster 1 (n= 51; 17.2%), Subcluster 2 (n= 170; 57.2%), and Subcluster 3 (n= 76; 25.6%). Since the score of every student in Subcluster 3 was 0, it was excluded from further analysis. The data from the two subclusters (n= 221) were then used as input for further clustering and created solution of five clusters. A final analysis using Pearson's correlation was employed to determine relationships between skills.
